dataset_name: RNA-SSP-Archive2 (RNA Secondary Structure Prediction - Archive2 Dataset)
description: This dataset addresses the fundamental problem of RNA secondary structure prediction using token-level classification. The task involves predicting the base-pairing pattern of RNA sequences using dot-bracket notation, where '(' and ')' represent paired bases (forming helical structures like stems) and '.' represents unpaired bases (forming loops, bulges, or single-stranded regions). Secondary structure prediction is crucial for understanding RNA function, RNA-protein interactions, drug target identification, and designing synthetic RNA molecules. The Archive2 dataset provides a curated collection of RNA structures from diverse RNA families.

label_distribution.0: Opening bracket '(' - left partner of base pair
label_distribution.1: Closing bracket ')' - right partner of base pair

sequence_length.description: Maximum sequence length, allowing for large RNA molecules including ribosomal RNAs

seq.description: RNA sequence in nucleotide string format (A, U, G, C)

label.description: Secondary structure in dot-bracket notation, same length as sequence

preprocessing.special_handling: Structure labels are converted to token-level labels corresponding to each position in the sequence. Special token positions (e.g., [CLS], [SEP]) are masked with label -100 to exclude them from loss calculation.

evaluation.notes: Evaluation considers whether the model correctly predicts paired vs unpaired regions. Advanced metrics may also assess base pair partner correctness and structure validity (balanced brackets).

biological_significance.structure_importance: RNA secondary structure is critical for molecular function, including catalysis (ribozymes), gene regulation (riboswitches), and protein synthesis (rRNA, tRNA)

notes: This dataset is part of the RGB (RNA Genomics Benchmark) suite and represents one of three secondary structure prediction benchmarks. The Archive2 dataset is relatively small but contains high-quality, manually curated structures. Models are trained to predict structure from sequence alone, mimicking the thermodynamic folding process. Success on this task demonstrates the model's ability to capture sequence-structure relationships and RNA folding principles encoded in genomic foundation models.
